Crime_Name: Judicial Review of Environmental Assessment and Duty to Consult
Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Legal_Provision_Involved: Section 16 of the Canadian Environmental Assessment Act (CEAA)
Grounds_for_Claim: Insufficient consultation and accommodation of Aboriginal rights
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of environmental assessment and project approval
Evidence_Requirement: Demonstration of adequate consultation and mitigation measures
Decision_Outcome: Crown's duty to consult was substantially satisfied
Institutional_Action: Federal Court review of Joint Review Panel process
Geographic_Context: Lower Churchill River region, Quebec and Labrador
Assessment_Standard: Significance of environmental effects on Aboriginal traditional use
Role_of_Person: Claimant: Le Conseil des Innus d'Ekuanitshit
Legal_Standard: Duty to consult and accommodate under Section 35
Protection_Claim: Preservation of traditional rights and land use
State_Protection_Assessment: Consultation found adequate despite minor deficiencies
Credibility: JRP findings accepted as reasonable by the Court
State_Protection_Adequacy: Deemed sufficient by the Federal Court
Risk_Nature: Potential adverse effects on Aboriginal rights from hydroelectric development
Enforcement_Action: Judicial review initiated, but no corrective enforcement ordered
Legal_Basis: Violation of duty to consult under Section 35
Victim_Basis: Indigenous community with established traditional land use
